data.text: @AriMeghlen Rofl, I found it hard to work through, but I guess I liked the twist about the door going to Wales because I'm Welsh. It was like he had a door to my neighbourhood. That and the drawing in my copy made Howl look like Gilderoy Lockhart and that amused me greatly XD
@EM_Writing Omg Yes!! I LOVE the movie, watched it like 3 days ago. Lol but I actually didn't like the book. By the end of was just like nah, bored.

@AriMeghlen OMG Howl's Moving Castle. THAT was the film I was trying to remember when I wrote this post. The film is amazing, but the book is barely recognizable. Totally worth trying both if you like very quick fantasy.

@AriMeghlen Exactly. Yes Man was a good film, but when I read the book the only thing that they'd taken was the premise. Personally, I prefer the book, but I think that's mainly because it has a very British sense of humour while the film is quite American. Not a problem, just a preference.

@EM_Writing I can understand that.  It's like, I believe World War Z is only similar to the book in title.  I enjoyed the movie for what it was.  If I read the book, I know it will be something completely different so I can enjoy it on its own terms too.

@AriMeghlen When they get so far away from the book there tends to be less to compare, so you can just judge the movie by itself. Im not saying they're perfect films, but I don't find them nearly as abrasive as straight adaptations.
@EM_Writing lol that's cool, I never really thought about book to movie adaptations that stand so far apart as to have their own merits.  Good point
